Bronchiolitis, Bronchitis, Common Cold,.Mode of Transmission: Breathing in respiratory droplets containing the pathogen after an infected person exhales, sneezes, or coughs -Direct contact with respiratory secretions from an infected person -Touching a contaminated object then touching mouth, nose or eyes
Bronchiolitis, Bronchitis, Common Cold,.Symptoms: Variable, including runny nose, watery eyes, fatigue, coughing, and sneezing.  May or may not have fever
Bronchiolitis, Bronchitis, Common Cold,.Period of Communicability: Variable, often from the day before symptoms begin up to 5 days after onset
Bronchiolitis, Bronchitis, Common Cold,.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: No exclusion unless febrile or other symptoms meeting exclusion criteria are present
Bronchiolitis, Bronchitis, Common Cold,.Reporting Requirement:
May depend of etiology/organism Report unusual illness, clusters of cases above baseline for group and time of year, or increased/unusual severity of illness to the
local health department

Conjunctivitis, Bacterial or Viral (Pink.Mode of Transmission: Contact with an infected person's skin, body fluid or though contact with a contaminated surface and then touching mucus membranes/eyes
Conjunctivitis, Bacterial or Viral (Pink.Symptoms:
Red eyes, usually with some discharge or crusting around eyes; may be itchy, sensitive to light, or watery
Bacterial: may have yellow/greenish discharge; may affect one or both eyes Allergic and chemical conjunctivitis usually affects both eyes
Conjunctivitis, Bacterial or Viral (Pink.Incubation Period: Bacterial: Unknown. Viral: Varies with etiology
Conjunctivitis, Bacterial or Viral (Pink.Period of Communicability:
Bacterial: from onset of symptoms until after start of antibiotics, or as long as there is discharge form the eye
Viral: variable, before symptoms appear and while symptoms are present
(Allergic and chemical conjunctivitis is not
contagious.)
Conjunctivitis, Bacterial or Viral (Pink.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Bacterial, Viral, or unknown etiology:
Exclude if conjunctivitis is accompanied by symptoms of systemic illness or if the child is unable to keep hands away from eye.
Childcare rules: exclude if purulent drainage until after 24 hours of treatment
http://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/adminc ode/089/089004070G03100R.html
Conjunctivitis, Bacterial or Viral (Pink.Reporting Requirement:
Not required to be reported
May notify local health department of large clusters of cases or cases with unusual severity of illness

Influenza.Mode of Transmission: Person to person by respiratory droplets created by coughing or sneezing, or though contact with a contaminated surface and then touching mucus membranes/eyes The virus can live on surfaces for several hours.
Influenza.Symptoms: Sudden onset of fever, chills, headache, malaise, body aches, and nonproductive cough
Influenza.Period of Communicability: Variable, from 24 hours before onset of symptoms, peaks during first 3 days of illness through 7 days
Influenza.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
For 24 hours until both are true: fever-free without using fever- reducing medications and symptoms are improving overall. Upon return and for the next 5 days, CDC recommends enhancing hygiene practices, wearing a well-fitted mask and physical distance from others when indoors as much as possible.
Criteria may differ in pandemic or novel/variant strain influenza situation.
Influenza.Reporting Requirement:
Influenza deaths in persons<18 years of age. ICU admissions are reportable within 24 hours.
Influenza A, variant virus cases are required to be reported immediately within 3 hours by healthcare providers.

Mumps.Mode of Transmission: Contact with droplets from eyes or mouth of infected person
Mumps.Symptoms: Fever with swelling and tenderness of one or both parotid glands located below and in front of the ears Unrecognized mild cases without swelling may occur.
Mumps.Period of Communicability: Peak infectious time begins 1 to 2 days before swelling to 5 days after but may range from 7 days before to 9 days after. For the purpose of contact tracing and exclusions, the infectious period is 2 days before to 5 days after parotitis.
Mumps.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude cases from school, childcare or workplace until 5 days after onset of parotitis.
Note: daycare licensing rules require 9 days exclusion; refer to link below. http://www.ilga.gov/commission/j car/admincode/089/089004070G 03100R.html
Susceptible contacts should be excluded from school or the
workplace from days 12-25 after last exposure.
Mumps.Reporting Requirement:
Report case to local health department within 24 hours.
Outbreaks: three or more probable or confirmed cases linked by time and place.

Pertussis (Whooping Cough).Mode of Transmission: Contact with droplets from nose, eyes or mouth of infected person
Pertussis (Whooping Cough).Symptoms: Initially cold-like symptoms, later cough; may have inspiratory whoop, post-tussive vomiting
Pertussis (Whooping Cough).Period of Communicability: Before cough onset (with onset of runny nose), continuing until child has been on antibiotics for 5 days If untreated, infectious for 3 weeks after cough begins
Pertussis (Whooping Cough).Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
School exclusion: Cases must be excluded from school until 5 days of appropriate antibiotic treatment is completed or 21 days after cough onset if no treatment is received.
Susceptible contacts do not need to be excluded unless they become symptomatic.
Pertussis (Whooping Cough).Reporting Requirement:
Report as soon as possible, within 24 hours
Outbreaks:  Five or more cases epidemiologically linked

RSV.Mode of Transmission: Highly contagious; contact with droplets from nose, eyes or mouth of infected person; virus can live on surfaces (toys, tissues, doorknobs) for several hours
RSV.Symptoms: Fever, runny nose, cough.  May have wheezing
RSV.Incubation Period: 2 to 8 days (4 to 6 days most common)
RSV.Period of Communicability: Variable, from the day before until 3 to 8 days or longer; may last up to 3 to 4 weeks
RSV.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: For 24 hours until both are true: fever-free without using fever- reducing medications and symptoms are improving overall. Upon return and for the next 5 days, CDC recommends enhancing hygiene practices, wearing a well-fitted mask and physical distance from others when indoors as much as possible.
RSV.Reporting Requirement: RSV deaths in persons<18 years of age and ICU admissions are reportable within 24 hours.

SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19).Mode of Transmission:
Breathing in air when close to an infected person who is exhaling small droplets and particles that contain the virus.
Having these small droplets and particles that contain virus land on the eyes, nose, or mouth, especially through splashes and sprays like a cough or sneeze.
Touching eyes, nose, or mouth with hands that have the virus on them.
SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19).Symptoms:
May have no symptoms or can have any of the following: Fever or chills, Cough,
Shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, Fatigue, Muscle or body aches, Headache,
New loss of taste or smell, Sore throat Congestion or runny nose, Nausea or vomiting, Diarrhea, dermatologic manifestations.
SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19).Period of Communicability: From 2 days before symptom onset through Day 10 after symptom onset
SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19).Criteria for Exclusion from School*: For 24 hours until both are true: fever-free without using fever- reducing medications and symptoms are improving overall. Upon return and for the next 5 days, CDC recommends enhancing hygiene practices, wearing a well-fitted mask and physical distance from others when indoors as much as possible.
SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19).Reporting Requirement:
COVID-19 deaths in persons<18 years of age and ICU admissions are reportable within 24 hours.
Outbreaks with hospitalization or deaths related to COVID-19 involving 3 or more in a core group of individuals within a 10-day period or if the school is no longer able to safely operate and provide essential services.

Strep throat/Scarlet Fever.Mode of Transmission: Contact with droplets from nose and mouth; close crowded contact, direct contact
Strep throat/Scarlet Fever.Symptoms: Fever, sore throat with pus spots on tonsils, tender swollen glands Scarlet fever has above symptoms plus a sandpaper-like rash Symptoms may vary.
Strep throat/Scarlet Fever.Period of Communicability: Highest during acute infection; no longer contagious within 24 hours after antibiotics
Strep throat/Scarlet Fever.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Schools: Exclude until fever free without the use of fever-reducing medications or symptoms improving if fever not present AND on appropriate antibiotics for AT LEAST 12 hours.
However, during outbreaks or in the setting of recurrent infection, IDPH recommends individuals stay home for at least 24 hours after on effective antibiotics AND fever free or symptoms improving if fever not present. Child Care: rules: Exclude until 24 hours after treatment has been initiated and until the child has been without fever for 24 hours;
http://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/adminc
ode/089/089004070G03100R.html
Strep throat/Scarlet Fever.Reporting Requirement:
Clusters of 10 epidemiologically linked cases of strep throat/scarlet fever within a 10-day period are reportable to the local health department.
Invasive disease from streptococcal bacteria is reportable.

TB (tuberculosis).Mode of Transmission: Airborne inhalation of droplets from nose and mouth of diseased person (children usually contract TB from close contact with a diseased adult)
TB (tuberculosis).Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, weight loss, cough (lasting 3+ weeks), night sweats, loss of appetite
TB (tuberculosis).Incubation Period:
2 to 10 weeks to years; risk of developing disease is highest 6
months to 2 years after infection
TB (tuberculosis).Period of Communicability: Individuals with infection but without active disease (latent TB) are not infectious. Individuals with active disease are infectious until treatment.
TB (tuberculosis).Criteria for Exclusion from School*: For active disease: after therapy started, adherence documented, symptoms diminished, and determined to be non-infectious; consult with public health officials; no exclusion for latent infection
TB (tuberculosis).Reporting Requirement: Report suspect or confirmed TB cases to local health department within 7 days

Campylobacteriosis.Mode of Transmission: Ingestion of undercooked meat, contaminated food or water, or raw milk
Campylobacteriosis.Symptoms: Diarrhea (may be bloody), abdominal pain, malaise, fever
Campylobacteriosis.Period of Communicability: Throughout illness (usually 1-2 weeks, but up to 7 weeks without treatment)
Campylobacteriosis.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude until diarrhea has ceased for at least 24 hours; additional restrictions may apply.
Campylobacteriosis.Reporting Requirement: Cases of campylobacteriosis are reportable to the local health department within 7 days.

C. diff (clostridium difficile) infectio.Mode of Transmission: Person-to-person through inadequate handwashing or on contaminated objects or surfaces, and ingestion of spores
C. diff (clostridium difficile) infectio.Symptoms: Diarrhea, may have fever, nausea, abdominal cramping
C. diff (clostridium difficile) infectio.Period of Communicability: During active infection (while symptomatic); can continue to shed spores when asymptomatic
C. diff (clostridium difficile) infectio.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude while symptomatic and until diarrhea has ceased for 24- 48 hours
C. diff (clostridium difficile) infectio.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases do not have to be reported. Clusters of cases should be reported to the local health department.

E. coli infections (E. coli O157:H7 and.Mode of Transmission:
Fecal-oral: person-to person, from
contaminated food or liquids, contact with infected animals
E. coli infections (E. coli O157:H7 and.Symptoms: Profuse, watery diarrhea, sometimes with blood
E. coli infections (E. coli O157:H7 and.Period of Communicability:
Typically, one week or
less in adults or up to 3 weeks in children
E. coli infections (E. coli O157:H7 and.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
School:  Exclude until diarrhea,
vomiting, and fever have ceased for at least 24 hours; additional
E. coli infections (E. coli O157:H7 and.Reporting Requirement: Report cases as soon as possible within 24 hours.

Salmonellosis.Mode of Transmission: Fecal-oral: person-to person, contact with infected animals or via contaminated food
Salmonellosis.Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhea (possibly bloody), fever, nausea, vomiting, dehydration
Salmonellosis.Period of Communicability: During active illness and until organism is no longer detected in feces
Salmonellosis.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude until diarrhea, vomiting, and fever have ceased for at least 24 hours; additional restrictions may apply.  Release specimens shall be required for food handlers, health care workers, and sensitive
occupation.
Salmonellosis.Reporting Requirement: Report cases as soon as possible within 7 days

Shigellosis.Mode of Transmission: Fecal-oral: frequently person-to- person; also via contaminated food or water
Shigellosis.Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhea (possibly bloody), fever, nausea, vomiting, dehydration
Shigellosis.Period of Communicability: During active illness and until no longer detected; treatment can shorten duration
Shigellosis.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude until diarrhea, vomiting, and fever have ceased for at least 24 hours; additional restrictions may apply.  Release specimens shall be required for food handlers, health care workers, and sensitive occupations.
Shigellosis.Reporting Requirement: Report cases as soon as possible within 7 days

Norovirus.Mode of Transmission: Contact with food, water or surfaces contaminated with vomit or feces, person-to-person, aerosolized vomit
Norovirus.Symptoms:
Nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, possibly low-grade fever, chills, headache
Duration of symptoms usually 12-72 hours
Norovirus.Period of Communicability: Usually from onset until 2-3 days after recovery; typically, virus is no longer shed after 10 days
Norovirus.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude until diarrhea, vomiting, and fever have ceased for 24hours
Exclude from food handling for 48 hours after recovery
Norovirus.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases do not have to be reported. Clusters of cases should be reported to the local health department.

Rotavirus.Mode of Transmission: By the fecal-oral route through direct contact or contact with contaminated hands, objects, food, or water
Rotavirus.Symptoms: Diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, fever, abdominal pain; may have loss of appetite and dehydration
Rotavirus.Period of Communicability: Usually from onset until 3 days after recovery
Rotavirus.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude until diarrhea, vomiting, and fever have ceased for 24hours
Exclude from food handling for 48 hours after recovery
Rotavirus.Reporting Requirement:
Individual cases do not have to be reported. Clusters of cases should be reported to the local
health department.

Hepatitis A.Mode of Transmission: By the fecal-oral route through direct contact, person to person, or ingestion of contaminated food or water
Hepatitis A.Symptoms:
Fever, loss of appetite, nausea, abdominal discomfort and weakness followed by jaundice.
Many unrecognized mild cases without jaundice occur, especially in children
Hepatitis A.Period of Communicability: Communicability greatest in 2 weeks before onset of illness, and through 7 days after onset of jaundice
Hepatitis A.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude from school and daycare for 7 days after onset of jaundice or for two weeks after onset of symptoms if no jaundice present Exclude food handlers, healthcare workers, or workers in sensitive occupations for 7 days after onset of jaundice, or two weeks after onset of initial
symptoms, if jaundice is not present
Hepatitis A.Reporting Requirement:
Report cases as soon as possible within 24 hours.
Outbreaks: Two or more cases linked by time and place.

Giardiasis.Mode of Transmission: By the fecal-oral route, ingestion of contaminated food or water, person-to-person transmission of cysts from infected feces; contaminated water (e.g. water play tables)
Giardiasis.Symptoms:
Nausea, bloating, pain, and foul-smelling watery diarrhea, excessive flatulence, nausea and stomach cramps; symptoms can recur several times over a period of weeks.  May be
asymptomatic.
Giardiasis.Period of Communicability: Highly variable but most infectious during diarrhea phase.
Giardiasis.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude until diarrhea has ceased for at least 24 hours; may be relapsing; additional restrictions may apply
Giardiasis.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases do not have to be reported. Clusters of cases should be reported to the local health department.

Cryptosporidiosis.Mode of Transmission: By the fecal-oral route, ingestion of fecally contaminated food or  water, contact with infected animals, consumption of contaminated unpasteurized food and drinks
Cryptosporidiosis.Symptoms:
Diarrhea, which can be profuse and watery, preceded by loss of appetite, vomiting, abdominal pain; asymp- tomatic cases can spread the infection to others;
symptoms can come and go for up to 30 days
Cryptosporidiosis.Period of Communicability: As long as the oocysts are being shed, typically days to weeks.  Shedding may persist after symptoms resolve.
Cryptosporidiosis.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude until diarrhea has ceased for at least 24 hrs; exclude from food handling and working in sensitive occupations for 48 hrs after recovery; exclude from swimming in public pools (or any recreational water venue)
while symptomatic and for 2 weeks after symptoms resolve
Cryptosporidiosis.Reporting Requirement: Report cases as soon as possible within 7 days

Bacterial.Mode of Transmission: Contact with droplets from nose, eyes or mouth of infected person
Bacterial.Symptoms:
Sudden onset, severe headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, stiff neck
May have petechial rash with Neisseria meningitidis
Can have behavioral changes including altered mental status
May have invasive disease with bacteremia or pneumonia
Bacterial.Period of Communicability:
Unknown; communicable for as long as the organisms are present in the nasopharynx.
No longer communicable after 24 hours of antibiotic therapy
Bacterial.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude until after at least 24 hours of antibiotic treatment received, including antibiotics to eliminate carrier state
Exclusion of contacts not indicated.
Bacterial.Reporting Requirement: H. influenza, Invasive disease and meningitis, Reportable as soon as possible, within 24 hours

Viral (usually enterovirus).Mode of Transmission: Contact with droplets from nose, eyes or mouth of infected person or fecal material, often from healthy people
Viral (usually enterovirus).Symptoms: Sudden onset, severe headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, stiff neck, behavioral changes
Viral (usually enterovirus).Period of Communicability: Viral shedding can occur from the day before illness until up to 2 weeks after onset.
Viral (usually enterovirus).Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude until fever resolved for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medication.
Viral (usually enterovirus).Reporting Requirement:
Individual cases are not reportable.
Clusters of cases are reported to local health department.

Chickenpox (Varicella).Mode of Transmission: Contact with the chickenpox rash or breathing in respiratory droplets containing the pathogen after an infected person exhales, sneezes, or coughs
Chickenpox (Varicella).Symptoms:
Fever and generalized rash.
There are usually two or three crops of new blisters that scab over then heal, sometimes leaving scars.
Disease in vaccinated children can be mild or absent of fever with few lesions, which might not be blister-like.
Chickenpox (Varicella).Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude until all lesions have crusted (and at least 5 days) For vaccinated children with atypical rash: exclude until
afebrile and no new lesions have developed for at least 24 hours Day Care licensing requirements: exclude at least 6 days after rash onset
http://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/adminc ode/089/089004070G03100R.html
No exclusion of susceptible contacts unless in a healthcare facility/setting.
Chickenpox (Varicella).Reporting Requirement:
Cases are reportable as soon as possible but within 24 hours.
Outbreaks are defined as 3 or more cases that are epidemiologically linked.

Fifth Disease (Human Parvovirus).Mode of Transmission: By breathing in respiratory droplets containing the pathogen after an infected person exhales, sneezes, or coughs
Fifth Disease (Human Parvovirus).Symptoms:
Redness of the cheeks and body, "slapped cheek" rash.
May have mild fever, runny nose, headache Rash may come and go
for weeks
Fifth Disease (Human Parvovirus).Period of Communicability:
Until rash appears
In immunosuppressed persons, communicability may last months-years
Fifth Disease (Human Parvovirus).Criteria for Exclusion from School*: No exclusion unless febrile or other symptoms meeting illness exclusion criteria are present

German Measles (Rubella).Mode of Transmission: Contact with droplets from nose, eyes or mouth of infected person; may be transmitted to fetus across the placenta
German Measles (Rubella).Symptoms: Red or pink rash appearing on face then spreading down the body; sore throat; swollen glands behind ears; low grade fever; may have joint pain
German Measles (Rubella).Period of Communicability:
From 7 days before until 7 days after the rash appears
Infants with congenital rubella can shed the virus for months.
German Measles (Rubella).Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude cases for 7 days after the onset of the rash.
Exclude susceptible contacts from school or the workplace from days 7-23 following rash onset after last exposure.
German Measles (Rubella).Reporting Requirement: Reportable as soon as possible, within 24 hours

Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease (Coxsackie Vi.Mode of Transmission: By breathing in respiratory droplets containing the pathogen after an infected person exhales, sneezes, or coughs -Touching feces or objects contaminated with feces, then touching mouth
Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease (Coxsackie Vi.Symptoms: Rash in mouth, hands (palms and fingers), and feet (soles); fever; loss of appetite; may be asymptomatic.
Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease (Coxsackie Vi.Period of Communicability: Most commonly during the first week of illness.  Can persist days to weeks after symptoms resolve.
Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease (Coxsackie Vi.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude with febrile illness or other symptoms meeting illness exclusion criteria.
Exclude if child cannot maintain hygiene (e.g. excessive drooling) or avoid contact with others.
Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease (Coxsackie Vi.Reporting Requirement:
Individual cases are not reportable.
Clusters of 10 epidemiologically linked suspect or confirmed cases within a 10 day period should be
reported to local health department.

Head Lice (Parasite).Mode of Transmission: Direct close person to person contact; less commonly through contact with contaminated objects
Head Lice (Parasite).Symptoms:
Itching and scratching of scalp; presence of live lice or pinpoint-sized white eggs (nits) that will
not flick off the hair shaft
Head Lice (Parasite).Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Childcare rules: exclude until the morning after the first treatment
http://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/adminc ode/089/089004070G03100R.html

Herpes Simplex (cold sores, skin lesions.Mode of Transmission: Direct person to person contact with lesions, secretions form lesions, or saliva
Herpes Simplex (cold sores, skin lesions.Symptoms:
Primary infections may have no symptoms; may have fever or malaise; may or may not have rash, vesicular lesions, or ulcers at site, "fever blister"/cold sore
HSV 1 and HSV2 lesions can appear on other
parts of the body.
Herpes Simplex (cold sores, skin lesions.Period of Communicability:
Most infectious while vesicular lesions are present.
May be present with no symptoms
Herpes Simplex (cold sores, skin lesions.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude from wrestling or contact sports (including practices) if lesions are present on the body (outside the genital area)
If large areas of lesions cannot be covered or if exposure to infectious lesions by other students cannot be avoided, the student should be excluded until
lesions are dried and crusted.
Herpes Simplex (cold sores, skin lesions.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases are not reportable.  Clusters of 2 or more suspect or confirmed cases within a 5 day period that are epidemiologically linked should be reported to the local health department.

Impetigo (Staphylococcus or Streptococcu.Mode of Transmission: Direct skin contact (especially through contaminated hands) or nasal discharge or contaminated surfaces
Impetigo (Staphylococcus or Streptococcu.Symptoms: Small red pimples or fluid filled blisters with crusted yellow scabs; most often found on face but may be anywhere on body
Impetigo (Staphylococcus or Streptococcu.Period of Communicability: Until active crusting lesions are gone or after 24 hours on antibiotics
Impetigo (Staphylococcus or Streptococcu.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Sores should be covered and child excluded at the end of the day, to return 24 hours after treatment is started.
Impetigo (Staphylococcus or Streptococcu.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases are not reportable.  Clusters of cases should be reported to local health department.

Measles (Rubeola virus).Mode of Transmission: Airborne or direct contact with droplets from nose, eyes or mouth of infected person
Measles (Rubeola virus).Symptoms: Cough, runny nose, conjunctivitis, fever, rash that starts at head and spreads down and out on body; sore throat; may have Koplik's spots
Measles (Rubeola virus).Period of Communicability:
From 4 days before until 4 days after rash onset.
Extremely contagious!
Measles (Rubeola virus).Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude for at least 4 days after start of rash.
Susceptible contacts: Those who do not receive vaccine within 72 hours of exposure shall be excluded for 21 days after onset of last case.
Measles (Rubeola virus).Reporting Requirement: As soon as possible, within 3 hours.

Mpox.Mode of Transmission: Direct skin contact with infected persons rash, scabs or body fluids, touching objects, fabrics (clothing, towels, bedding) and surfaces that have been used by someone with MPV or contact with respiratory secretions.
Mpox.Symptoms: Fever, headache, muscle aches/backache, swollen lymph nodes, chills, exhaustion, respiratory symptoms (sore throat, nasal congestion, or cough), and a rash that may be located on or rear the genitals or anus but can be located other places like the hands, feet, chest, face and mouth. The rash might look like pimples or blisters and may be painful or itchy.
Mpox.Incubation Period: Roughly 1 to 2 weeks. If flu- like symptoms develop, they usually develop a rash 1 to 4 days later.
Mpox.Period of Communicability:
From onset of prodrome until the rash has healed, all scabs have fallen off and a fresh layer of skin has formed. This illness typically lasts 2 to 4 weeks.
Prodrome of fever, malaise, headache sometimes sore throat and cough, and lymphadenopathy usually occurs 1-2 days before rash
onset.
Mpox.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude until the rash has healed, all scabs have fallen off and a fresh layer of skin has formed.
Mpox.Reporting Requirement: As soon as possible, within 24 hours.

MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus.Mode of Transmission:
Direct skin contact with infected person, wound drainage or contaminated surfaces; increase
risk in crowded conditions;
MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus.Symptoms:
Skin lesions such as furuncles (abscessed hair follicles or "boils"),
carbuncles (coalesced
MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus.Incubation Period:
Variable, usually 4-10 days and up to
months; at
MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus.Period of Communicability:
Duration of acute illness if wound drainage present
Draining wounds are
MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude if wound drainage cannot be well contained under a dressing
MRSA (Methicillin-resistant Staph aureus.Reporting Requirement:
Individual cases are not reportable.
Clusters of 2 or more cases with infections in a

Mode of Transmission: occasional transmission by droplet over short distances
Symptoms: masses of furuncles), and abscesses; may have purulence (pus), yellow/white central point, redness
Incubation Period: times initially mistaken as spider bite
Period of Communicability: very contagious and should be covered at all times.
Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude from high-risk activities such as contact team sports if wound cannot be completely covered with a secure bandage that will remain intact throughout sport activity, until completely healed
Exclude from use of pools/whirlpools, etc. until wounds are healed
Reporting Requirement: 14-day period and with an epidemiological link should be reported to local health department.

Molluscum contagiosum.Mode of Transmission: Person to person close contact; through sharing of objects such as towels
Molluscum contagiosum.Symptoms: Small flesh colored bumps on the skin that may have a tiny indented center
Molluscum contagiosum.Incubation Period: 2 to 7 weeks, as long as 6 months
Molluscum contagiosum.Period of Communicability: When lesions are present; otherwise unknown
Molluscum contagiosum.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
No exclusion.
Provide education on importance of hand hygiene and avoiding scratching areas.
Molluscum contagiosum.Reporting Requirement:
Individual cases are not reportable.  Clusters of cases should be reported to local health
department.

Ringworm (e.g. tinea corporis, tinea ca.Mode of Transmission: Direct skin contact with infected person or animal, or contact with surfaces or objects contaminated with fungal spores
Ringworm (e.g. tinea corporis, tinea ca.Period of Communicability: From onset of lesions until treatment begins and lesion begins to shrink
Ringworm (e.g. tinea corporis, tinea ca.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
If lesion can be kept covered, exclusion are not required.
If lesions can NOT be kept covered, exclude from school until 24 hours after treatment begins.
Ringworm (e.g. tinea corporis, tinea ca.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases are not reportable.  Clusters of cases should be reported to local health department.

Scabies.Mode of Transmission: Prolonged skin-to-skin contact with infested individual; contact with bedding or clothes of infested person
Scabies.Symptoms: Red bumps commonly found in skin folds; burrows appear as tiny whitish or gray lines on skin surface; intense itching, especially at night
Scabies.Incubation Period:
4 to 6 weeks,
1 to 4 days after re- exposure
Scabies.Period of Communicability: From up to 8 weeks before skin rash appears until it has been treated with a scabicide
Scabies.Criteria for Exclusion from School*:
Exclude from school and other extracurricular activities until the morning after treatment recommended by the child's healthcare provider has been started.
Childcare rules: exclude until the morning after the first treatment.
http://www.ilga.gov/commission/jcar/adminc ode/089/089004070G03100R.html
Scabies.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases are not reportable.  Clusters of cases should be reported to local health department.

Shingles/Zoster.Mode of Transmission: Direct contact with the rash during blister phase
Shingles/Zoster.Symptoms: Painful rash that develops typically on one side of the body; may have fever, headache, chills, nausea
Shingles/Zoster.Incubation Period: None. Anyone with history of chicken pox can develop shingles.
Shingles/Zoster.Period of Communicability: Shingles cannot be passed from one person to another, but during the blister phase of rash, direct contact with blister fluid of shingles rash can cause chicken pox in non-immune persons.  When crusted over, rash is no longer infectious.
Shingles/Zoster.Criteria for Exclusion from School*: Exclude if rash cannot be covered, or if child cannot comply with keeping rash covered until crusted over. Exclude if febrile or other symptoms meeting illness exclusion criteria are present
Shingles/Zoster.Reporting Requirement: Individual cases are not reportable.  Clusters of cases should be reported to local health department.

Bat Exposures/Animal Bites (Potential fo.Mode of Transmission:
